questions.text: What is the embryonic origin of the lens?
questions.solution:
The lens of the eye originates embryonically from the surface ectoderm.

Surface ectoderm gives rise to lens, conjunctival and corneal epithelium and epithelial lining of lacrimal glands and tarsal glands.

questions.text: Where are the youngest fibers of the lens present?
questions.solution:
The youngest fibers of the lens are the peripheral part, the cortex. 

The nucleus of the lens is the central part containing the oldest fibers.

The lens fibers are produced by mitosis of the epithelial cells in the pre-equatorial zone. As the lens fibers elongate and the new ones are formed, the older ones are pushed towards the depth of the lens so that the youngest fibers are the most superficially located.

questions.text: At a routine ophthalmological check-up, a patient was found to have bilateral, Y-shaped lens opacities as shown below. He was diagnosed with suture cataracts. Which zone of the lens nucleus is not involved here?
questions.solution:
The primary fibers in the embryonic nucleus of the lens do not form Y-shaped sutures. 

The image shows bilateral cataracts in the Y-shaped sutures of the lens. These are very slowly progressive congenital cataracts and do not require any surgical intervention. 

 Types of lens nucleus and their age of development: 

  • Embryonic nucleus: Innermost nucleus formed at around 1–3 months of gestation
  • Fetal nucleus: From 3 months of gestation till birth
  • Infantile nucleus: From birth to puberty
  • Adult nucleus

As lens fibers grow anteriorly and posteriorly, a pattern emerges where the ends of the fibers meet. These patterns of cell association are known as sutures. 

Y-shaped sutures are recognizable at about 8 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: What is the ligament of Weigert?

choices.text: Attachment of the vitreous to the posterior capsule of the lens
Attachment of the lens to the ciliary muscles

questions.solution:
The hyaloideo-capsular ligament of Weigert is the attachment of the vitreous to the posterior capsule of the lens. 

It is the annular region (1–2 mm in width and 8–9 mm in diameter) where the vitreous is attached to the posterior aspect of the lens.

Erggelet’s or Berger’s space is at the centre of the hyaloideo-capsular ligament, a potential space between the vitreous and the lens. The canal of Cloquet arises from this space and courses posteriorly through the central vitreous, which is the former site of the hyaloid artery in the embryonic vitreous.

Posteriorly, Cloquet’s canal opens into a funnel-shaped region anterior to the optic disc, whch is known as the area of Martegiani.

questions.text: Where does the crystalline lens derive its nutrition from?
questions.solution:
The crystalline lens derives its nutrition from the aqueous humor.

The lens is an avascular structure. It receives nutrition mostly from the aqueous humor and, to some extent, from the vitreous humor as well. Glucose is the main energy source. Major intrinsic protein 26 (MIP 26)/Aquaporin 0 in the lens is responsible for maintaining transparency by transporting water and glycerol across the lens.

Anti-oxidant mechanisms in the lens: 

  • Reduced glutathione (most important)
  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • Superoxide dismutase
  • Catalase
  • Vitamin C, Vitamin E, carotenoids.

questions.text: While studying the histological anatomy of the lens, you are measuring the thickness of the lens capsule in various areas. At which of the following zones would you get the lowest measurement?
questions.solution:
The lens capsule is the thinnest at the posterior pole, measuring 4 µm. 

Other options:

Option A: At the anterior pole, the thickness of lens capsule is 14 µm. 

Option C: In the pre-equator region, lens capsule is the thickest, measuring 23 µm. 

Option D: At the equator, as shown in the illustration below, the thickness is 17 µm.

questions.text: You are observing the given slide in a histology examination. Where is the marked structure absent?
questions.solution:
The slide shows the histology of the lens and the structure marked in the subcapsular epithelium. The epithelium of the lens is absent on its posterior surface.

The lens epithelium is a single layer of cells on the anterior surface of the lens. There is no epithelium on the posterior surface, as these cells are used up in filling the central cavity of the lens vesicle during the development of the lens. The anterior epithelial lining creates new lens fibers throughout a person's life.

questions.text: Ascorbate and alpha-tocopherol are maintained in the lens in the reduced state by _______.
questions.solution:
Ascorbate and alpha-tocopherol are maintained in the lens in the reduced, functional state by glutathione.

Glutathione is present in high concentrations in the lens, particularly in the epithelial layer. One of its key functions is to maintain protein thiols in their reduced state, which preserves the lens transparency by preventing the formation of high molecular weight crystalline aggregates and protects the lens from oxidative stress. 

The lens is highly prone to photochemical reactions from continuous exposure to ultraviolet rays (295–400 nm), leading to reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation. Its defence relies heavily on superoxide dismutase, ascorbate, catalase and glutathione peroxidase. 

With ageing or cataracts, levels of glutathione and ascorbic acid (in reduced form) significantly decrease.

questions.text: As part of a public health initiative,  screening for cataract is being carried out.  What is the most common cause of this healthcare issue in the population?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of cataracts is ageing, specifically senile (age-related) cataract. 

Important causes of cataract:

  • Aging (Most common)
  • Congenital cataract (crystallin gene - CRYAA, CRYAB, CRYGC, CRYGS) (Option A)
  • Diabetes mellitus (Option B)
  • Syndermatotic- atopic dermatitis is the most common skin condition associated with cataract
  • Galactosemia- reversible cataract
  • Radiation- UV rays, X-rays, gamma rays, infrared
  • Toxic agents- Corticosteroids, miotics (long-acting anticholinesterases, e.g., echothiophate) (Option C)
  • Obesity

Senile cataract is the most common type of acquired cataract and is also known as age-related cataract. The two types of senile cataracts are cortical (soft cataract)-75% and nuclear (hard cataract)-25%. In cortical cataract, the cuneiform type (70%) is the most common, and the cupuliform type is the most visually handicapping. 

Related Pearl: Maturation of Cortical Cataract

1. Stage of lamellar separation 

2. Stage of incipient cataract- cuneiform and cupuliform patterns can be made out at this stage.

 

3. Immature senile cataract: 

  • The lens is greyish white.
  • Clear cortex is still present, so iris shadow is visible
  • Untreated immature cataracts can progress and develop into intumescent cataracts as a result of swelling and congestion of the lens due to degeneration of lens proteins.

 

4. Mature cortical cataract/ Ripe cataract 

  • The opacification is complete
  • The lens is pearly white

 

 

5. Morgagnian hypermature cataract

  • The whole cortex liquefies and the lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid.
  • The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, altering its position with a change in the position of the head.

questions.text: You are compiling a literature review on congenital cataracts diagnosed in the last few years. Which of the following is the most common type?
questions.solution:
The most common type of congenital cataract is the blue-dot cataract.

Cataracta-punctata-caerulea, commonly known as blue dot cataract, is a prevalent type of congenital cataract. It typically develops during the first two decades of life. This condition is characterized by distinctive rounded bluish opacities located in the peripheral region of the adolescent nucleus and the deeper cortical layers of the lens. While these opacities are generally stationary and do not impair vision, larger ones may cause slight visual disturbance. 

Related Pearl: Types of Congenital Cataract

Punctate cataract: Blue-dot cataract, most common congenital cataract

 

Zonular/Lamellar cataract: Most common congenital cataract with diminished vision; Spokes of a wheel appearance (Rider’s Cataract) A, B, and C

 

Fusiform/coralliform cataract: Anteroposterior spindle shaped appearance. 

 

Nuclear cataract: Most common type of cataract seen in congenital rubella syndrome

 

Coronary cataract: Appears as a corona of club-shaped opacities near the periphery of the lens.

 

Anterior polar cataract: May arise either due to delayed development of anterior chamber or due to corneal perforation

 

Posterior polar cataract: Progressive form of posterior polar cataract, which typically shows an "onion whorl appearance"

questions.text: The parents of a child have been informed at a PTA meeting that he has a lot of incomplete classwork. On being questioned, the child complains that he is unable to see things clearly and is having difficulty in reading and writing. On ophthalmic examination, he is found to have a cataract. Which type of congenital cataract most commonly presents with these findings?
questions.solution:
Lamellar or zonular cataract is the most common type of congenital cataract presenting with visual impairment.

The etiology may be either genetic or environmental in origin.

  • Genetic- familial autosomal-dominant
  • Environmental form is associated with:
    • Vitamin D deficiency
    • Hypocalcemia
    • Sometimes, maternal rubella infection contracted between the 7th and 8th week of gestation may also cause lamellar cataract.

The main mass of the lens internal and external to the zone of cataract is clear.

Small linear opacities like spokes of a wheel (riders) may be seen towards the equator.

 

Related Pearl: Types of Congenital Cataract

Punctate cataract: Blue-dot cataract, most common congenital cataract

 

Zonular/Lamellar cataract: Most common congenital cataract with diminished vision; Spokes of a wheel appearance (Rider’s Cataract) A, B, and C

 

Fusiform/coralliform cataract: Anteroposterior spindle shaped appearance. 

 

Nuclear cataract: Most common type of cataract seen in congenital rubella syndrome

 

Coronary cataract: Appears as a corona of club-shaped opacities near the periphery of the lens.

 

Anterior polar cataract: May arise either due to delayed development of anterior chamber or due to corneal perforation

 

Posterior polar cataract: Progressive form of posterior polar cataract, which typically shows an "onion whorl appearance"

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman delivers a baby girl with a congenital rash, as shown below, and patent ductus arteriosus. What type of cataract is commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario showing blueberry muffin rash, combined with patent ductus arteriosus in a baby girl, suggests a diagnosis of congenital rubella syndrome, which is typically associated with a progressive, pearly white nuclear cataract. 

Ocular effects of rubella:

  • Microphthalmia
  • Rubella keratitis
  • Angle-closure glaucoma
  • Nuclear pearly cataract
  • Salt and pepper fundus (a most common ocular feature of rubella) due to diffuse chorioretinitis.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

Related Pearl: Ocular manifestation in infections

  • Congenital microphthalmos

questions.text: The following finding is found on the ophthalmologic examination of an 18-year-old girl. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image above characteristically depicts a Christmas tree cataract, featuring multiple refractile colors commonly observed in myotonic dystrophy.  

Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder characterised by difficulty relaxing skeletal muscles after contraction. The initial symptoms typically manifest during adolescence or early adulthood. 

Cataracts are an early and prominent feature in 90% of patients with myotonic dystrophy. They typically present as fine, dust-like opacities interspersed with iridescent, polychromatic spots in the cortical layer beneath the anterior and posterior lens capsule, resembling a Christmas tree. These cataracts may remain stable or progress. 

Surgical outcomes are generally favourable.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmology OPD with the findings shown below. She has been diagnosed with a right-sided senile cataract. Identify the stage of the cataract.
questions.solution:
The above image represents an advanced stage of cataract progression characteristic of a Morgagnian hyper-mature cataract.

Morgagnian hyper-mature cataracts are characterized by liquefaction of the entire cortex. The lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid. The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, its position altering with a change in the position of the head.

Senile cataract is the most common type of acquired cataract and is also known as age-related cataract. The two types of senile cataracts are cortical (soft cataract)-75% and nuclear (hard cataract)-25%. 

Cortical cataract is further divided into the cuneiform and cupuliform types.

Cuneiform (70%) Posterior subcapsular/Cupuliform (5%)

Radial spoke-like opacity starting in the periphery and extending centrally

Central saucer-shaped opacity in the posterior cortex just below the capsule

Late visual loss

Early loss of visual acuity; most visually handicapping senile cataract 

Nuclear cataracts: These may be pigmented due to the deposition of urochrome pigments. These are cataracta brunescens (brown), cataracta nigra (black), cataracta rubra (red).


Related Pearl: Maturation of Cortical Cataract

1. Stage of lamellar separation 

2. Stage of incipient cataract- cuneiform and cupuliform patterns can be made out at this stage.

 

3. Immature senile cataract: 

  • The lens is greyish white.
  • Clear cortex is still present, so iris shadow is visible
  • Untreated immature cataracts can progress and develop into intumescent cataracts as a result of swelling and congestion of the lens due to degeneration of lens proteins.

 

4. Mature cortical cataract/ Ripe cataract 

  • The opacification is complete
  • The lens is pearly white

 

 

5. Morgagnian hypermature cataract

  • The whole cortex liquefies and the lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid.
  • The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, altering its position with a change in the position of the head.

questions.text: Where is polychromatic luster noted?
questions.solution:
Polychromatic luster is seen in complicated cataracts.

Due to disturbances in nutrition of the lens due to inflammatory/degenerative disease of other parts of the eye like iridocyclitis and ciliary body tumors. In inflammations/degenerations affecting the posterior segment, a characteristic opacification is seen in the posterior part of the cortex in the axial region (posterior subcapsular cataract).

These cataracts present with a breadcrumb appearance and polychromatic luster. Even in the early stages, vision is impaired.

questions.text: Who among the following patients can potentially develop drug-induced cataracts?
questions.solution:
Patients taking dexamethasone (corticosteroid) are prone to drug-induced cataracts, predominantly presenting as discoid posterior subcapsular cataracts. 

Drugs causing cataracts:

Drugs Type of cataract
Corticosteroids Discoid, posterior subcapsular
Anticholinesterases Anterior subcapsular
Chlorpromazine Yellow-brown anterior capsular granules/stellate/anterior polar 
Busulfan Posterior subcapsular
Chloroquine White, flaky, posterior subcapsular
Amiodarone Anterior subcapsular

Other options:

Option A: Zoledronate, a bisphosphonate drug can cause orbital inflammation, uveitis, and scleritis. 

Option B: Hydroxychloroquine, a drug used in malaria and rheumatoid arthritis, does not cause cataracts, chloroquine does. It can rarely cause retinal toxicity. 

Option D: Ethambutol is used in anti-tubercular therapy and its use has been shown to cause optic neuritis.

questions.text: The ophthalmologic examination on a 23-year-old college student revealed the following image. What disease is commonly associated with this ocular finding?
questions.solution:
The given picture of a slit-lamp biomicroscope examination depicts the anterior lenticonus, which is associated with Alport syndrome. 

In Alport’s syndrome, both anterior and posterior lenticonus are seen, but anterior lenticonus is more common. The diagnosis of lenticonus is typically confirmed through slit-lamp examination. 

Note: Lowe’s syndrome is an oculo-cerebro-renal syndrome characterized by congenital cataract, glaucoma, and posterior lenticonus

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, diagnosed with bilateral cataracts two months ago, reports being able to read better without prescription glasses. However, he complains that his distant vision has become blurrier. Which type of cataract typically causes this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon described is the second sight of old age, seen in nuclear cataracts.

Due to nuclear sclerosis, there is an increase in the refractive index, causing progressive myopia. A patient with presbyopia may be able to read again, without the aid of spectacles. This improvement in vision is termed second sight.

Related Pearl: Important symptoms and their occurrence in cataract

Symptom Condition
Monocular diplopia or polyopia Cortical cataract (Incipient stage)
Color shift Nuclear cataract
Index hypermetropia Cortical cataract
Loss of ability to see objects in bright sunlight, blinded by the light of oncoming headlamps when driving at night Posterior subcapsular cataract and Nuclear cataract
Second sight/ Myopic shift/ Index myopia Nuclear cataract
Fluctuating refractive error Diabetic cataract (due to fluctuating blood sugar levels)

questions.text: A 38-year-old lady is a known case of diabetes and is on insulin for the last 8 years. Her sugars are poorly controlled and now she complains of hazy vision. What type of cataract will be characteristically noted in her eyes?
questions.solution:
The typical appearance of a diabetic cataract is a snowflake cataract.

Hyperglycemia is reflected in a high level of glucose in the aqueous humor, which diffuses into the lens. Here, glucose is metabolized into sorbitol, which accumulates within the lens, resulting in secondary osmotic overhydration.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with an inability to see objects in bright light. On examination, she is diagnosed with a cataract. In which of the following cataract is this characteristic finding not seen?
questions.solution:
The inability to see objects in bright light is not a feature of cuneiform cataract, as the lens opacity is peripheral, allowing visibility in bright light during miosis. 

The loss of the ability to see objects in bright light is a feature of posterior subcapsular cataract (visually handicapping), cupuliform cataract and nuclear cataract as these present with central opacities.

When a person is exposed to bright light, the pupil undergoes miosis (constriction). These central opacities come to lie directly in the path of axial rays, allowing no transmission of rays. Therefore, there is an inability to see objects in bright light. However, in dim light, when there is mydriasis (dilatation of the pupil), some rays may pass around the opacity, leading to an improvement in dim-light vision.

Furthermore, the complicated cataract, steroid-induced cataract, radiation-induced mainly present with a posterior subcapsular cataract and therefore have a similar clinical picture. 

Related Pearl: Maturation of Cortical Cataract

2. Stage of incipient cataract- cuneiform and cupuliform patterns can be made out at this stage.

 

3. Immature senile cataract:

  • Clear cortex is still present, so iris shadow is visible

questions.text: You are counseling the parents of Nisha, a 1-month-old child diagnosed with a congenital lamellar cataract in both eyes. What is the course of treatment you would advise?

choices.text: Cataract surgery with intraocular lens (IOL) implant
Pars plana lensectomy with no IOL implant

questions.solution:
Cataract surgery with an intraocular lens (IOL) implantation is the treatment of choice in congenital cataracts.

It involves an extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) with primary posterior capsulorhexis and anterior vitrectomy. After removal of the cataractous lens, a posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL) is implanted.

The critical period for the development of the fixation reflex in both unilateral and bilateral visual deprivation disorders is 2–4 months of age. Thus, any cataract dense enough to impair vision must be dealt with before this age, and the earliest possible time is preferred. 

  • Bilateral dense cataract- early surgery by 4-6 weeks of age
  • Unilateral dense cataract or involving visual axis- urgent surgery within days

Intracapsular cataract extraction (ICCE) is contraindicated in children.

questions.text: A 28-year-old girl is being evaluated for an aortic root aneurysm. She says her mother died of an aortic dissection at the age of 43. She is tall and slim. A musculoskeletal system finding is shown below. What is the most common lens subluxation noted in the genetic disease she is suffering from?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a girl with tall, slim stature, an aortic arch aneurysm, Steinberg sign (positive thumb sign), and similar family history suggest a diagnosis of Marfan’s syndrome. It is most commonly associated with a superotemporal subluxation of the lens.

The image below shows a subluxated lens in a patient with Marfan's syndrome. 

Congenital subluxation of the lens is called ectopia lentis.

Types of ectopia lentis are as follows:

  • Simple type
  • Ectopia lentis et pupillae (pupil also displaced in opposite direction)
  • Ectopia lentis associated with syndromes
    • Marfan’s syndrome- superotemporal subluxation of lens
    • Homocystinuria- inferonasal subluxation of the lens
    • Weill–Marchesani- downward, forward subluxation of the lens.
    • Ehler–Danlos syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following diseases does not show a specific pattern of cataract?
questions.solution:
A specific pattern of cataract is not seen in leprosy.

A specific pattern of cararact is seen in the following: 

  • Juvenile diabetes: Snowflake cataract
  • Myotonic dystrophy: Christmas tree cataract
  • Wilson's disease: Sunflower cataract
